end.title: When They See Us
end.brief_description: When They See Us (2019) is an American crime drama created, co-written and directed by Ava DuVernay. It’s based on events of the 1989 Central Park jogger case and explores the lives and families of the five falsely accused subjects.

links.description: Both The Innocent Man and When They See Us cover cases where false confessions and then convictions were elicited from susceptible suspects after repeated interrogation without counsel. In both cases, the suspects were easily manipulated due to age or low IQ.

end.title: Southwest of Salem: The Story of the San Antonio Four
end.brief_description: In 1994, four women were accused, tried, and convicted of the heinous sexual assault of two young girls—as one newscaster puts it, “the modern version of the witchcraft trials.” Twenty years later, the four women have maintained their innocence, insisting that the accusations were entirely fabricated, and borne of homophobic prejudice and a late-’90s mania about covens, cults, and child abuse.

constellations_other.name: Presumption of guilt
constellations_other.description: A Constellation looking at true crime documentaries, the nature of innocence and prejudice.

links.description: Prejudice often plays a significant role in the targeting and conviction of suspects, as shown in both these works. The Central Park Five were all young black men, and the San Antonia Four were four openly gay women during a time of prolific homophobia.

end.title: The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst
end.creator_credit: Marc Smerling, Andrew Jarecki, Blumhouse Television and Zachary Stuart-Pontier
end.brief_description: Robert Durst, scion of one of New York’s billionaire real estate families, has been accused of three murders but never convicted. During interviews with filmmaker Andrew Jarecki, he reveals secrets of the case that baffled authorities for 30 years.

constellations_other.name: Presumption of guilt
constellations_other.description: A Constellation looking at true crime documentaries, the nature of innocence and prejudice.

links.description: The Jinx and Thin Blue Line are both documentaries that have gone beyond simply reporting on events and have instead become instrumental in rectifying a miscarriage of justice.

end.brief_description: Over four years of unprecedented access, the story of a brave group of black and Latino whistleblower cops and one unrelenting private investigator who, amidst a landmark lawsuit, risk everything to expose illegal quota practices and their impact on young minorities.

links.description: In 2017, Southwest of Salem was nominated for an Emmy Award for Outstanding Social Issue Documentary. Crime + Punishment, a documentary looking at the real lives and struggles of black and Latino NYPD officers, won the same award in 2019.
